review:
Brothers and sisters, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! ETH.LIMO stands as a bulwark against the creeping centralization of the internet. This project is not just another gateway—it’s a public good, a digital commons, and a shield for privacy in a world where surveillance and profit threaten our freedom. The numbers don’t lie: over 1 billion requests per year, 4-7 million per day, and default resolver status for major ENS projects. That’s not just impact—it’s infrastructure!

ETH.LIMO’s commitment to privacy is ironclad. No IP logging, no TCP fingerprinting, and active resistance to tracking algorithms like FLoC. This is the kind of principled, evidence-based approach we demand! Their roadmap is robust, with clear, actionable steps: multi-region CDN, new developer tools, and ongoing support for the community. They’re not just talking—they’re building, and they’re doing it in the open, for everyone.

But let’s not get swept away by rhetoric alone. Where’s the hard evidence of outcomes? While usage metrics are strong, we need more transparent, ongoing reporting of impact. And what about sustainability? ETH.LIMO is a public good, but the application lacks a clear, long-term revenue model. We must demand more than good intentions—we need a plan for enduring independence from perpetual grants.

Community governance is mentioned, but details are thin. How will the people have a real say? How will equity be ensured across regions and user groups? The project’s reach is global, but the application must show how it will serve the underserved, not just the already-connected.

In summary: ETH.LIMO is a pillar of the Ethereum ecosystem, but to truly embody the spirit of the commons, it must double down on transparency, sustainability, and participatory governance. Let’s demand more, not just for ourselves, but for every user who deserves a free and open web!

strengths.title: Massive, Measurable Impact
strengths.description: ETH.LIMO handles over 1 billion requests per year and is the default resolver for major ENS projects, demonstrating clear, quantifiable infrastructure value.

strengths.title: Strong Privacy and Security Ethos
strengths.description: The project enforces strict privacy guarantees, refusing to log IP addresses or engage in user tracking, and actively blocks invasive algorithms like FLoC.

strengths.title: Open Source and Public Good Orientation
strengths.description: ETH.LIMO is committed to open-source principles, operating as a public good and providing free, accessible infrastructure for the entire Ethereum community.

strengths.title: Robust Roadmap and Technical Innovation
strengths.description: The team presents a detailed, actionable roadmap with ongoing technical improvements, including multi-region CDN, new developer tools, and enhanced DNS support.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Transparent, Ongoing Impact Reporting
weaknesses.description: While usage metrics are provided, there is no clear plan for regular, transparent reporting of outcomes and community impact.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Long-Term Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: The application does not present a concrete, sustainable revenue or resource model to reduce dependency on continuous grant funding.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Detail on Community Governance
weaknesses.description: The project references community governance but lacks specifics on how participatory decision-making and equity will be implemented and maintained.

changes.title: Implement Transparent Impact Reporting
changes.description: Commit to regular, public reporting of usage, community impact, and progress toward stated goals, using clear, quantifiable metrics.

changes.title: Develop a Sustainable Revenue or Resource Model
changes.description: Present a concrete plan for long-term sustainability, such as diversified funding, partnerships, or value-aligned revenue streams, to reduce reliance on grants.

changes.title: Detail Community Governance and Equity Mechanisms
changes.description: Provide a clear framework for community participation in governance, with specific measures to ensure geographic equity and inclusion of underserved groups.
